MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Sugar Imports.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the total tonnage and value of raw and refined sugar imported into this country from January to October, 1968; and the justification for this importation, in view of the statement of one of the chiefs of the Sugar Company that too much sugar was being produced in this country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Blaney) Neil T. Blaney
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Blaney)
Speaker.P: Imports of raw sugar this year up to the end of August, the latest month for which official figures are available, amounted to 41,621 tons, valued at £866,035. Imports of refined sugar in the same period were 222 tons valued at £9,562.

I understand from Comhlucht Siúicre Éireann that the imports of raw sugar are required to enable sugar to be supplied at an economic price for the export trade in sugar-containing goods. The imports of refined sugar consisted mainly of special types of sugar for which there is only a very limited demand in this country.

Does the Minister consider that there is any justification for importing that amount of foreign sugar to date this year while, at the same time, the Sugar Company are complaining that the farmers are growing too much beet and that too much sugar is being produced?

The question at issue is not whether I agree or disagree. This is something the Sugar Company and the beet growers arranged to operate between them. From the information I have available, the Sugar Company, from the imports and dealings in sugar—that is imported and raw sugar—make, and I imagine will continue to make, a profit on these transactions. I have no doubt that this is to the benefit of the overall financial structure of the Sugar Company, not only in regard to its sugar-making enterprises but also in regard to its vegetable processing in Erin Foods.

Is the Minister aware that this allegation of too much sugar has been used by the Sugar Company to deprive the beet growers of 11/- a ton to which they are entitled and which amounts to £580,000 from the beet growers' proceeds?

I know from the operations of the Sugar Company and from the growers' representatives over the years that this matter of price has been arranged between them in practically all cases and in an amicable and satisfactory manner. I hope that this system of reasonable arrangements in regard to pricing for the farmers' produce will continue to operate in the future as it did in the past.
That arrangement has been broken, as the Minister is aware.
As the Deputy and the House are aware, I have not got this particular State body under my control at any level.
All right, we have a remedy.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Bord Iascaigh Mhara Employees.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if there is any obligation on Bord Iascaigh Mhara to compensate employees who suffer loss as a result of their transfer to another part of the country.

The Board pays to transferred officers their cost of travelling to the new centre and subsistence allowance there for a reasonable period depending on the circumstances to enable them to obtain suitable living accommodation. In addition, in the case of each married officer the Board defrays the actual removal expenses of the family and the household effects. The Board is under no other obligation.

My information from Bord Iascaigh Mhara is that in the past three years seven transfers took place. There were three cases in the past 12 months, two in the previous year and two in the year before that, and the method of compensation which I have outlined in my reply was applied in all these seven cases. No claim was made for additional compensation nor is there any claim for such under consideration.

This man was transferred from Dingle to Dublin and had started to build a house because he was going to get married. He was transferred in order to provide a job for the secretary of a Fianna Fáil Cumann in Turner's Cross in the Taoiseach's constituency, and for no other reason. Now he is threatened with another transfer to Killybegs and I would not wish that on him.
I will have to look into this transfer to Killybegs because this might well displace a Fianna Fáil Cumann secretary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. O'Donnell Mr. P. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: You are right, but you can promote him.

My thanks to the Opposition for all this information. An Bord Iascaigh Mhara effected these transfers and I had no hand, act or part in them or knowledge of them. If the allegation the Deputy makes is true I am unaware of any substance in it. On the other hand, if he can show that something has been done that should not have been done or done for the wrong reason, certainly as Minister responsible to some degree for An Bord Iascaigh Mhara I will have it investigated.
If they give the Minister the details?
Sure.
I am giving it exactly as I got it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Dunne Mr. S. Dunne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will abolish the three-mile limit laid down for the free transport of schoolchildren and introduce a one-mile limit so as to facilitate children where schools are not available in any area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Colley) (for the Minister for Education) George Colley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Colley) (for the Minister for Education)
Speaker.P: The free transport schemes have been introduced to enable children from remote areas to attend post-primary schools. The distance limit of three miles is not unreasonable and I am not prepared to make any change in it. I might add for the Deputy's information that at present 83,500 children are being provided with free transport to school.

As the Deputy will be aware, for quite a number of years there has been free transport for primary schools. The regulation has provided for quite a number of years for free transport for children who live more than two miles from school and who are aged up to ten years; above that, they had to live three miles or more from the school. That has been the practice for a long time and was considered reasonable. This question relates to post-primary pupils. If it was reasonable for children above 10 years of age, attending primary schools, then it should be reasonable for pupils attending post-primary schools.
Is it reasonable to ask a child to walk three miles to school and the same journey home, a journey which would take from threequarters of an hour to an hour each way?
I am sure the Deputy is aware that most of the children in the post-primary schools who are now benefiting from this scheme were, in fact, cycling——
Is it reasonable to ask a young child to walk for nearly an hour, there and back, between his home and the school?
I think that in the circumstances of this country and, in particular, the advances which have been made in the educational field in a very short time, this is very reasonable.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Closure of Wicklow School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Timmins Mr. Timmins Mr. M.J. O'Higgins Mr. M.J. O'Higgins
Speaker.P: and Mr. Timmins asked the Minister for Education if he will make a statement as to the position of the national school in Kilmacoo, County Wicklow; and if it is intended to reopen it.

I am fully satisfied that, in order to make proper provision for the educational needs of the Kilmacoo children, the only course open to me was to amalgamate the Kilmacoo school with the school in Avoca.
In the circumstances, there can be no question of reopening the school at Kilmacoo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.J. O'Higgins Mr. M.J. O'Higgins
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that this decision was taken against what seemed to be the unanimous desire of the parents and that, in fact, there has been a strike in progress since this decision was taken and that the parents have refused to send the children to Avoca? Could the Minister say to what extent there have been any discussions or further consideration given, in view of that situation?
I am glad the Deputy said it “seemed” to be the unanimous view of the parents.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.J. O'Higgins Mr. M.J. O'Higgins
Speaker.P: The “seemed” is only as to “unanimous”. If it is not unanimous it is virtually unanimous.

My information is that a number of parents would be prepared to avail of the free transport service into Avoca but for certain pressure brought to bear on them by other parents who take a very strong view in these circumstances. The Deputy will be familiar with the fact that these arrangements have been made in the interests of the children. In the past 20 years, there have been eight qualified principal teachers in this school and there have been a number of unqualified teachers in the school for prolonged periods. Because of this and of a similar situation arising again, the Department decided that the thing to do in the interests of the children attending the school was to amalgamate. I understand the position has been explained fully to the parents. It is true that many of them do not accept the Department's view on this but experience shows, I think, in similar instances in different parts of the country that some of those who have been most vociferous in their opposition are those who have appreciated most the benefits of the amalgamation scheme afterwards.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.J. O'Higgins Mr. M.J. O'Higgins
Speaker.P: Is it a fact that there are no children who formerly went to Kilmacoo National School now going to Avoca because the parents have refused to send them? In other words, is there a strike in progress? Is it still in progress?
I understand that is correct.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.J. O'Higgins Mr. M.J. O'Higgins
Speaker.P: Does the Minister agree that there are about 60 pupils concerned in this instance who are not now being educated at all as far as school-going education is concerned because of the Department's decision to close down this school? Furthermore, is the condition of this school first-class as far as repair, and so on, are concerned? Is it in first-class condition and is it a fact that the parents in the area were eminently satisfied with the teaching given in the school before it was closed down?
My information is that the condition of the school was fair: I certainly would not say it was poor. The school was built in 1933, or thereabouts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.J. O'Higgins Mr. M.J. O'Higgins
Speaker.P: About 35 years ago.

The Deputy will also appreciate that while the condition of the schoolroom is important the quality of the education being imparted in the school is very important. I have indicated to the House the frequent change of principal teacher there and the prolonged period when unqualified persons were teaching there. That cannot have been in the best interests of the children attending the school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.J. O'Higgins Mr. M.J. O'Higgins
Speaker.P: Surely it is better to have them going to school than to have the present position?

The difficulties that arise from this come to light only when the children have left school and are seeking employment. Experience in different parts of the country has shown that this is in the long-term interests of the children. The school in Avoca to which it is proposed to bring them now has five teachers and will soon be a six-teacher school where they will get a much wider curriculum and better educational facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.J. O'Higgins Mr. M.J. O'Higgins
Speaker.P: The Minister referred to the school having been there for 35 years: I think that is correct so far as the present building is concerned. Does the Minister appreciate that there has been a school in this area since 1870 and that there is a tradition of education in the area which I suggest to the Minister should be preserved? Finally, in view of the unsatisfactory nature of the Minister's reply, I give notice that I wish to raise this matter on the Adjournment.

Free Books and Accessories, 1968/69
Grants towards free books and accessories may be paid in respect of necessitous pupils in secondary schools in the school year 1968/69 in accordance with the terms of this memorandum.

1. The scheme applies to necessitous pupils who are receiving free education under the terms of circular M.15/67. Fee-paying pupils are not included except that necessitous day pupils who hold scholarships may be given assistance to the extent that the annual amount of the scholarship falls short of the combined cost of the fees and books.

Where a pupil transfers from one post-primary school to another after commencement of the school year he should not be given assistance under the scheme in the second school unless the Headmaster is satisfied that he has not already been given free books or has returned any free books already supplied to him in this school year.

2. For the purposes of the scheme a necessitous pupil may be defined as a child from a home where genuine hardship exists because of unemployment, prolonged illness of parent, large family with inadequate means, mother a widow, etc.

3. The grant in respect of each individual pupil may vary in accordance with the course followed by him but on average it may be reckoned at £8 for the first year of the Intermediate Certificate course and £4 for each of the subsequent years of that course, at £10 for the first year of the Leaving Certificate course and £5 for any subsequent year. These figures would include the cost of copy books and other accessories.

The full cost or part of the cost of books and accessories for a pupil may be paid. The purchase of second-hand books is allowed provided such books are examined by the Headmaster with a view to ascertaining that they represent good value. Books in Christian Doctrine are included in the scheme.
Books and accessories supplied by means of a grant to individual pupils become the property of the pupils.
4. Should a Headmaster prefer to operate a loan scheme, he may do so on the understanding that books provided in this manner shall remain the property of the school.

5. A provisional allocation of money for the purposes of the scheme is being paid to each school. The expenditure of the full amount of this provisional quota is not permitted unless the number of necessitous pupils warrants it.
Discounts received from booksellers should be used for the purposes of the scheme.
If any amount of the provisional allocation is not required for the purposes of the scheme for the school year 1968/69 the amount not required must be returned to the Department as soon as possible.

6. An estimate of the full extent of the need for assistance in each school in the school year 1968/69 should be forwarded to the Department as soon as possible but not later than the 13th September, 1968. A form (LS/3) is enclosed for the purpose. This information is required in order that the final allocation for each school may be decided at an early date and, accordingly, all Headmasters are requested to be so good as to co-operate by furnishing the estimates in time.

7. The Department will not be prepared to reimburse Headmasters for expenditure in excess of the provisional allocations unless the prior approval of the Department for the excess has been given. Applications for increases in the provisional allocations will be examined by the Department in the light of the information supplied in the returns referred to in paragraph 6 of this memorandum. Each application should be accompanied by a statement of the circumstances giving rise to it.

Where the number of pupils considered in need of assistance under the scheme exceeds 25% of the number of day pupils in a school it is urged that a loan scheme, rather than a scheme of grants to individual pupils, be introduced. It will not be possible to make sufficient money available to enable direct grants to be given to more than 25% of the day pupils in schools generally.

8. It is no longer necessary to furnish to the Department the names of the pupils benefiting under the scheme but the enclosed Form LS/1 properly completed, must be furnished in respect of all money expended for the purposes of the scheme.

The Minister for Education wishes to inform Managers and Principal Teachers that he has decided to introduce a revised scheme for the provision of free books for necessitous pupils on rolls in 2nd to 6th standards in National Schools. The grant will be at the rate of £1 per year for each necessitous pupil in these standards and will be calculated as shown in paragraph 4.

2. For the purposes of the scheme a necessitous pupil may be defined as a child from a home where genuine hardship exists because of unemployment, prolonged illness of parent, large family with inadequate means, mother a widow, etc.

3. Managers and Principal Teachers were asked in October, 1967, to furnish statistics, on a form specially prepared for the purpose, of the percentage of necessitous pupils on the roll in 2nd to 6th standards in each school. The information asked for has not yet been supplied in respect of many schools. No grant can be paid until the form duly completed has been returned to the Department.

4. The amount of the grant payable in each of the next five years will be based on the application of the percentage of necessitous pupils as shown on the form referred to in paragraph 3 to the average number of pupils on rolls in 2nd to 6th standards for the previous school year, e.g.
Percentage of necessitous pupils=20%
Average number of pupils in 2nd to 6th standards for year ended 39th June=80
Amount of grant=20% of 80 X £1=£16.
The figures already furnished on the form which issued in October, 1967, will suffice to make this year's payment.

5. The grant will be paid to the Principal Teacher in the June Quarter each year. Formal application for the grant will not be necessary. The Principal Teacher will ensure the proper disbursement of the grant and will account for the expenditure on all books purchased by him for the pupils. For this purpose a simple accounting form has been devised for completion and retention in the school records. A five year supply of the form is being sent to each school.

Discounts received from booksellers should be used for the purposes of the scheme. The accounting form when completed should be countersinged by the school manager and should be available for inspection by the Department's officers.
6. Books supplied under the scheme shall be the property of the pupils. The pupils should be instructed to care for the books and have them covered.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Payment of Secondary Teachers.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if secondary school teachers are only paid quarterly; and, if so, if there is any reason why they cannot be paid monthly.

Incremental salary is payable quarterly to registered secondary teachers but monthly advances are payable at the option of the teacher. In fact, the majority of teachers are paid monthly advances. Similar provisions apply to the payment of the relevant allowance to teachers engaged in serving the year of teaching experience necessary for registration except that it is not possible to pay an advance in the first quarter of the school year, because of the necessity, before any payment may be made, of verifying that the conditions governing payment have been satisfied in each case. These conditions include prescribed academic qualifications and teaching hours.

It is entirely in respect of the first quarter that I am concerned. It involves young teachers starting off. They come up from the country, they have to get digs and that can amount to considerable hardship. They are three months in digs in Dublin before they get any money from the Department.

This can only apply in the first quarter of probationer teachers. There are about 700 of these and it is necessary for the Department to verify, in the case of each of the 700, that they have the necessary educational qualifications—the higher diploma in education and the required number of teaching hours. This means consultation with the schools to verify the timetables in the case of each of the 700. It is not possible to do this in a time shorter than the first quarter.

It is hard to accept this—to think it should take three months when a teacher is being employed for the first time. Surely the schools concerned have to require certain qualifications before they take on the teacher in the first instance. It should be accepted by the Department that only qualified teachers are employed in secondary schools.
It is necessary to verify this and it takes time.
